captions.text: When I was little,
I thought my country was the best on the planet,
and I grew up singing a song called "Nothing To Envy."
And I was very proud.
In school, we spent a lot of time
studying the history of Kim Il-Sung,
but we never learned much about the outside world,
except that America, South Korea, Japan are the enemies.
Although I often wondered about the outside world,
I thought I would spend my entire life in North Korea,
until everything suddenly changed.
When I was seven years old, I saw my first public execution,
but I thought my life in North Korea was normal.
My family was not poor,
and myself, I had never experienced hunger.
But one day, in 1995, my mom brought home a letter
from a coworker's sister.
It read, "When you read this, all five family members
will not exist in this world,
because we haven't eaten for the past two weeks.
We are lying on the floor together,
and our bodies are so weak we are ready to die."
I was so shocked.
This was the first time I heard
that people in my country were suffering.
Soon after, when I was walking past a train station,
I saw something terrible
that I can't erase from my memory.
A lifeless woman was lying on the ground,
while an emaciated child in her arms
just stared helplessly at his mother's face.
But nobody helped them, because they were so focused
on taking care of themselves and their families.
A huge famine hit North Korea in the mid-1990s.
Ultimately, more than a million North Koreans
died during the famine, and many only survived
by eating grass, bugs and tree bark.
Power outages also became more and more frequent,
so everything around me was completely dark at night
except for the sea of lights in China,
just across the river from my home.
I always wondered why they had lights but we didn't.
This is a satellite picture showing North Korea at night
compared to neighbors.
This is the Amrok River,
which serves as a part of the border
between North Korea and China.
As you can see, the river can be very narrow
at certain points, allowing North Koreans to secretly cross.
But many die.
Sometimes, I saw dead bodies floating down the river.
I can't reveal many details [about] how I left North Korea,
but I only can say that during the ugly years of the famine
I was sent to China to live with distant relatives.
But I only thought
that I would be separated from my family for a short time.
I could have never imagined
that it would take 14 years to live together.
In China, it was hard living as a young girl without my family.
I had no idea what life was going to be like
as a North Korean refugee,
but I soon learned it's not only extremely difficult,
it's also very dangerous,
since North Korean refugees are considered in China
as illegal migrants.
So I was living in constant fear
that my identity could be revealed,
and I would be repatriated to a horrible fate
back in North Korea.
One day, my worst nightmare came true,
when I was caught by the Chinese police
and brought to the police station for interrogation.
Someone had accused me of being North Korean,
so they tested my Chinese language abilities
and asked me tons of questions.
I was so scared,
I thought my heart was going to explode.
If anything seemed unnatural, I could be imprisoned
and repatriated.
I thought my life was over,
but I managed to control all the emotions inside me
and answer the questions.
After they finished questioning me,
one official said to another,
"This was a false report.
She's not North Korean."
And they let me go. It was a miracle.
Some North Koreans in China seek asylum
in foreign embassies,
but many can be caught by the Chinese police
and repatriated.
These girls were so lucky.
Even though they were caught,
they were eventually released
after heavy international pressure.
These North Koreans were not so lucky.
Every year, countless North Koreans are caught in China
and repatriated to North Korea,
where they can be tortured, imprisoned
or publicly executed.
Even though I was really fortunate to get out,
many other North Koreans have not been so lucky.
It's tragic that North Koreans have to hide their identities
and struggle so hard just to survive.
Even after learning a new language and getting a job,
their whole world can be turned upside down in an instant.
That's why, after 10 years of hiding my identity,
I decided to risk going to South Korea,
and I started a new life yet again.
Settling down in South Korea was a lot more challenging
than I had expected.
English was so important in South Korea,
so I had to start learning my third language.
Also, I realized there was a wide gap
between North and South.
We are all Korean, but inside,
we have become very different
due to 67 years of division.
I even went through an identity crisis.
Am I South Korean or North Korean?
Where am I from? Who am I?
Suddenly, there was no country
I could proudly call my own.
Even though adjusting to life in South Korea was not easy,
I made a plan.
I started studying for the university entrance exam.
Just as I was starting to get used to my new life,
I received a shocking phone call.
The North Korean authorities
intercepted some money that I sent to my family,
and, as a punishment, my family was going
to be forcibly removed
to a desolate location in the countryside.
They had to get out quickly,
so I started planning how to help them escape.
North Koreans have to travel incredible distances
on the path to freedom.
It's almost impossible to cross the border
between North Korea and South Korea,
so, ironically, I took a flight back to China
and I headed toward the North Korean border.
Since my family couldn't speak Chinese,
I had to guide them,
somehow, through more than 2,000 miles in China
and then into Southeast Asia.
The journey by bus took one week,
and we were almost caught several times.
One time, our bus was stopped
and boarded by a Chinese police officer.
He took everyone's I.D. cards,
and he started asking them questions.
Since my family couldn't understand Chinese,
I thought my family was going to be arrested.
As the Chinese officer approached my family,
I impulsively stood up, and I told him
that these are deaf and dumb people
that I was chaperoning.
He looked at me suspiciously,
but luckily he believed me.
We made it all the way to the border of Laos,
but I had to spend almost all my money
to bribe the border guards in Laos.
But even after we got past the border,
my family was arrested and jailed
for illegal border crossing.
After I paid the fine and bribe,
my family was released in one month,
but soon after, my family was arrested and jailed again
in the capital of Laos.
This was one of the lowest points in my life.
I did everything to get my family to freedom,
and we came so close,
but my family was thrown in jail
just a short distance from the South Korean embassy.
I went back and forth between the immigration office
and the police station,
desperately trying to get my family out,
but I didn't have enough money
to pay a bribe or fine anymore.
I lost all hope.
At that moment, I heard one man's voice ask me,
"What's wrong?"
I was so surprised
that a total stranger cared enough to ask.
In my broken English, and with a dictionary,
I explained the situation, and without hesitating,
the man went to the ATM
and he paid the rest of the money for my family
and two other North Koreans to get out of jail.
I thanked him with all my heart, and I asked him,
"Why are you helping me?"
"I'm not helping you," he said.
"I'm helping the North Korean people."
I realized that this was a symbolic moment in my life.
The kind stranger symbolized new hope for me
and the North Korean people when we needed it most,
and he showed me the kindness of strangers
and the support of the international community
are truly the rays of hope we North Korean people need.
Eventually, after our long journey,
my family and I were reunited in South Korea,
but getting to freedom is only half the battle.
Many North Koreans are separated from their families,
and when they arrive in a new country,
they start with little or no money.
So we can benefit from the international community
for education, English language training,
job training, and more.
We can also act as a bridge
between the people inside North Korea
and the outside world,
because many of us stay in contact
with family members still inside,
and we send information and money
that is helping to change North Korea from inside.
I've been so lucky, received so much help
and inspiration in my life,
so I want to help give aspiring North Koreans
a chance to prosper
with international support.
I'm confident that you will see more and more
North Koreans succeeding all over the world,
including the TED stage.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: Hyeonseo Lee: My escape from North Korea

comments.text:
"North Korea is not socialist! 
They obviously need more socialism in that country". - dumb Trotskyist 

Let's ignore the fact everyone who defected from that nation is heavily 
anti communist/socialist. And they have very low economic freedom! Which is 
a massive problem in that nation. 
Yes, economic freedom = Capitalism 
Of course dumb commies would deny this. Because communist always love to 
play with words (it's hilarious) economic freedom is what capitalism is, 
completely! This fact is undeniable even the definition agrees. So go ahead 
and deny, and I will make you cry! 

So if you dumb communist learn what economic freedom is you would realise, 
that it has led to prosperity and a better environment. And personal 
freedom and other liberties. It been growing wealth in nations and did 
amazing things.

A country with low economic freedom can lead to tyranny, mass poverty, 
dictatorship and horrible things. 
And "no" Economic freedom = collectivism = socialism

So North Korea defectors flee because they have no economic freedom, people 
who flee end up starting a private business. Like this girl in this video! 
Something you cannot do in Socialist totalitarian North Korea. Yeah all of 
defectors are pro-businessman and pro-capitalist!

So if any stupid Trotskyist want to challenge me, let's go! Because you 
will get owned, I swear I will make you cry! Tell me how you will fix the 
country? 

Because no one in North Korea wants to give communism another try and I'm 
sorry! But that's the truth and it seems like capitalism and economic 
freedom is the only solution to that country.

Sorry Trotskyist but you lose!

﻿
comments.author: TheNoraa890

comments.text:
Many ignorant fools below are claiming that communism is horrible and evil, 
and that the DPRK has to fall, however, something you should know is that 
the DPRK is NOT communism in ANYWAY besides name. Then again its also a 
"democracy" in name too, so just because it has the label "Communist" and 
*looks* "Communist", it doesn't mean it *is* communist. Look at Cuba, it is 
communist and it is a thriving nation, nothing like the DPRK. 

Communism is united the market, preventing scams by making the law dynamic, 
while this isn't an official explanation for what communism is, its exactly 
what the USSR was back in the days of my grandfather. People who tried 
being clever and trick others by manipulating the solidified law, soon 
realised the law wasn't as they thought it was. For example, today skin 
moisturisers say stuff in scientific nonsense which when translates into 
english usually means "This lotion uses water and moisturising isotopes", 
but they say it in such words that people think it has some kind of magical 
thing in it. The USSR wouldn't allow that, because while they are not 
breaking the law, they are tricking people. 

I hate it when capitalists hate communism and fascism despite having NO 
idea what the difference is between these three systems. You fools.

Bottom line for you morons, don't believe everything you are taught, 
history is written by the victors, hence why capitalism is praised so much.﻿
comments.author: White Dragon (Harut Rehanyan)

comments.text:
imagine if Chinese government officially announces that China will help NK 
defectors transit to SK, what will happen? Does NK government will not have 
any reflection? The fact is that the border of china and NK will certainly 
be an another 38th parallel which is riddled with mines and machine gun to 
prevent the escape. Everyday, some people will be killed, because they fail 
to escape from NK.

Not only that, most foreigners does not know that, many NK people will 
starve if Chinese and NK government reinforce their border management. 
Because of the loose border management, many goods and food made in China 
can be transited to black market in NK and NK people can buy them to 
support their life. 

Many people blame China repatriates NK defectors. However I will tell you 
the truth. This girl said she has lived in China for ten years! I can't 
imagine she supported her own life without help from any people. During the 
period of living in China, she had been accused by people for once and the 
Chinese policemen let her go. Does her really think that she can speak 
Chinese mandarin fluently to outfox policemen? China also has a strict 
system of citizen's identification card. This girl said she showed her ID 
card to policemen, but does she really think that the policemen didn't know 
her identification? The fact is that the provision of repatriating the NK 
defectors was not really implemented in grass-roots cadres of China. 

You guys may also not know that until now there are at least 200,000 NK 
defectors who live in China, especially for the northeast China region, but 
SK government only accepts a few of them ( 2k-4k) every year. Why, because 
NK defectors does not has any social skills. Imagine that if 200,000 people 
suddenly flood in SK and SK government can not provide enough jobs for 
them. What will happen. It will results in crime and economic downturn!

Whether repatriating the NK defector or not will involves many things, I 
don not think Chinese government handle it well, but I really believe that 
government try to help NK defectors and balance respective interests.﻿
comments.author: Wenhan Li

comments.text: +Wenhan Li Well she did it she is in America now she is safe ;)

comments.author: jeffer torres

comments.text:
Why this girl blame CHINA. China have their own intersts.
China's support of North Korea is a very strategic move that also involves 
historical influences.

Historical:
China has been NK's ally for so long that it cannot just abruptly decide to 
stop supporting it. This is similar to how China still claims itself to be 
a "socialist country with Chinese twist", even though the economy is 
practically capitalist.

Strategic (the most important reasons)
Shield to Japan. North Korea has been publicly against Japan, and as recent 
disputes involving oil-drilling and territory claims in the Pacific between 
China and Japan arise, it is crucial to have a country between China and 
Japan so that Japan thinks wisely before it does something. Recent military 
reports indicate that Japan views North Korea as its primary military 
threat, not China. This is because although China is a lot stronger, it is 
also burdened by its international reputation, and that it has to at least 
pretend to go by the international rules. For example, it cannot just 
randomly declare war on Japan and shoot missiles. On the other hand, North 
Korea is so isolated internationally that even if it fires a few missiles 
in Japan's way, they will have a lot less consequence relatively.
Shield to the US. Although China has been supporting North Korea, it is 
very unlikely China will publicly supply North Korea weapons should it go 
to war with South Korea. It may do it secretly, or do it publicly and 
blatantly deny it, but it cannot do it directly. As a result, almost all 
analysts will agree that should the war start, South Korea, with the 
support of the US, is bound to win. If this were the case, the US military 
will have access to all of the peninsula, and can drive its troops all the 
way to Chinese borders. This is perhaps the biggest reason why China 
doesn't want Korea to unite.
Refugees from NK. If the war occurs between North and South Korea, millions 
of North Korean refugees will flee across the border to north-eastern 
China. This will cause great social disruption to China, and China 
definitely does not want it to happen.


China believes its best interest is served by keeping North and South Korea 
unstable enough that they cannot cooperate fully, but stable enough so that 
a war doesn't happen. If North and South Korea seems to be on the way to 
unite peacefully, China will definitely do everything it can to stop it 
from happening. Contrarily, if North and South Korea seem to be on the way 
to war, China will also try to prevent that. Keeping the unstable yet 
stable status quo yields the greatest benefits for China.﻿
comments.author: Bing Xu

comments.text:
So, in China they test people who they accuse of being North Korean if they 
can speak Chinese, and if they can, they are considered "Chinese"?
Man, I wish I could do the same in Germany. I speak German better than most

People from North Korea illegally living in China. The whole video is kind

The thing is, things can only change when there's a revolution inside North 
Korea. South Koreans have tried so many things. When we sent them trucks of 
food supplies, they just used it on the military and on building missiles. 
When we cut them off and warned them, they threatened to start a war and 
sent off missiles everywhere. Fact is, nothing can change as long as the 
dictatorship remains. There has to be something, a political dispute, a 
disagreement, a chance for the young generations to speak out. This

comments.author: gymnopedie

comments.text:
I lived in S. Korea for over 13 years- as a soldier and as a civilian.  On 
a positive note- our S. Korean brothers and sisters are very strong- many 
very well educated, strong family orientation- family first, business 
minded and quite resilient!  South Korea- as a country is no longer on any 
list as " 3rd World ", but now has a thriving economy and is getting 
expensive too.  Unfortunately, for the N. Korean folks, this is not the 
case; one party, selfish, uncaring and deliberate, in control of the fate 
of an entire country and watching their own people starve to death.   The 
N. Korean people are taught from birth that we, American people are the 
devil and should be killed on the spot- Some day soon, we need to end all 
of this, open the DMZ- which I have visited on many occasion myself.  Even 
for this hardened soldier, being on the DMZ can put the fear of God in your 
heart- when I looked across into N. Korea from the South, I could actually 
feel the devil at play!  For those of you who have not visited the DMZ., I 
would strongly recommend a visit!  I'm sure when you leave the DMZ you will 
feel as I did- a new feeling of freedom and being a very proud American. 
 We need to set those people free- as we did in Germany.  S. Korean's fear 
reunification- there will be an uncontrollable flow of N. Korean's seeking 
refuge in the South- economical issues will exist for sure, but it can be 
accomplish and I hope it happens during my lifetime- My dear wife of 34 
years if from S. Korea and I'm sure she shares the same feelings and 
thoughts as I do.﻿

comments.text:
+Chris Gerhart Sorry Chris...gotta call bravo sierra on your take on 
fluoride.  The fluoride in toothpaste is also a compound, as it the 
fluoride in the water (outlawed in most every single country in the world 
except for the USA, Australia, and parts of Canada).  

Your insinuation that I would believe everything I read or heard on the 
internet is silly and insulting.  It also exudes your own thought process 
in how you approach the world.  If you cannot think on your own, you 
shouldn't be insulting others that do.  It's not about 'belief'...it's 
about facts.  Whether I 'believe' that 2+2=4 or not is irrelevant.  As 
whether or not I 'believe' the fact, the fact is true.  Belief does come 
into play for those that cannot think for themselves.  For those poor 
buffoons, 2+2=5 because someone told them it was true.  And they have no 
choice but to 'believe' what they've been told...because they cannot think 
for themselves or reason it out.  Understand the difference?

In regards to cyano groups, I cannot know what their effect is in the human 
body, nor could anyone else until experiments have been conducted to study 
it.  But certainly, statistical analysis can shed some light on the issue, 
take for example, the increase in vaccination schedules and the lockstep 
increase in cases of autism.  I will not take a supplement which contains a 
'cyano' group.  The one good example of this is cheap vitamin B12, which 
contains cyano-cobalamin.  The stuff has been proven to break down in the 
body into its constituent parts, i.e...cyanide and the rest of it.  The 
cyanide corrodes the brain cells.  But this is not as dangerous as fluoride 
has been proven to be since the 1930s.  

Fluoride has been put in our water supply for a reason for sure...but it 
has nothing to do with the reasons claimed.  It is a chemical pacifier. 
 And fluoridated water has been shown conclusively to soften bones, cause 
cancer, kill brain cells, damage heart muscles, and cause rapid tooth 
decay.  The American Dental Association makes big cash off of the fluoride 
industry.  The tooth decay has been proven in research conducted in Canada 
between the two provinces of Ontario and Quebec, where one province gave 
into the lobbying pressure of the fluoride industry and began fluoridating 
its water.  At the moment of its inception, the tooth decay 
'hockey-sticked' upward.  

Wake up, you have been deceived.

comments.text:

they have covalently bonded fluorines in their structure.
several SSRI's also have cyano groups, but it doesn't mean they have the

everything you read on the internet.

I think you need to put down the tin foil hat and stop being so paranoid.

It does not take a chemistry degree to discuss the dangers of fluoride. 
 Other's have thoroughly established its properties and its biochemical 
uses.  Zoloft, for example, consists of 74% fluoride compounds for its mood 
altering effects.  Translation, it calms the mind (puts you into a passive 
state).  Right where the government wants you.  

And for the record, you will find nothing useful in a 'chemistry' book

about the phytochemical properties of herbs to learn how to cook."  It's

comments.text:
+John McClure The organic constitution was lost to us well before most of 
our great grandparents parents time.  Replaced by a corporate constitution 
by the bankers in 1871 (to satisfy these rapacious financial criminals for 
defaulting on the debt of the war of 1812).  The important distinction 
between that organic constitution and the corporate constitution was that 
the wording was slightly changed, and some omissions (to allow lawyers to 
hold public office).  The critical change was this..."The constitution for 
these united states"...changed to "The constitution of the united states". 
 Before this, it was well understood that each state was an independent 
country unto itself.  And the common law ruled the People.  Since then, 
this 'common law' has been largely abrogated in favor of maritime law (also 
known as contract, Roman, public, and statutory law).  Before we lost this 
law, based on over 800 years of case history, the claimant ruled the 
courts...the judge (magistrate) was just a powerless administrator.  Our 
Zionist controlled media has spent billions over decades insuring that the 
sheople of America never find out what we lost.  Though, it may be argued, 
that we still have the common law available to us.  The problem is that 
most courts refuse to hear cases based in this jurisdiction, because 
maritime law is a never-ending cash cow for the state.  The rights of the 
individual are superseded in favor of this (many) hundred billion dollar 
industry.  And this is one of political Zionisms linchpins of control over 
the once proud and well informed People of the republic.  If you can't get 
your fair day in court under well established law...you aren't free.  You 
are a subject.  

The water you drink is poisoned with fluoride.  The food you eat is 
poisonous and loaded with preservatives, chemicals, and other cancer 
causing additives, the money you use it debt based, the taxes you pay does 
nothing but impoverish you and stress you and eat your life substance out 
at the core (and they follow you around as an American 'citizen'), the

government lies to you on a daily basis and is bought and paid for by

it's to their advantage, they'll let you see some propaganda...but 
virtually everything else is just a fat disgusting lie.  

1868 - 14th amendment passed to enslave the People as a new class known as 
'citizens'.  
1871 - The original united states defaulted on the 1812 war debt and the 
organic constitution was changed into a corporate constitution with 
critical freedoms removed, while the D.C. entity was bankrupted and

holiday session.  
The Federal Reserve Act, passed later in the same year under similar

1919 - League of Nations and Women's suffrage passed (to double

1937 - Complete abrogation of common law.

because he was printing is own currency.  Millions killed worldwide for

1954 - UCC codified, to take advantage of the abrogation of common law.  
1955 - First US city Fluoridates water supplies.  Hitler and Stalin were 
long noted to have fluoridated water in concentration camps and Ghulags to 
pacify the prisoners.  The Nazi's claimed it was their number one method of 
controlling the camp inmates.  
Polio vaccines launched countrywide.  Thousands killed outright, thousands 
more paralyzed.  Dangerous Green Monkey cancer causing virus' intentionally 
laced into vaccines.
 
Somewhere along the way, agency government was enacted (mostly during FDR's 
early calamitous ventures into socialism).  The CIA, FBI, DOE, DOD, DHS, 
ATF, BLM, IRS, EPA...on and on it went and on and on it goes.   The 
department of education ensures the minds of American children are 
thoroughly sanitized and brainwashed into the state's idiotocracy, as 
permitted by the Zionist master puppeteers.  The TV does the rest.  

Everything we've been sold is a lie...spoon-fed to us by criminal agents of 
a foreign banker elite.  And America is nothing more than an Israeli 
colony...in all but name alone.  

Wake up, you have been deceived.

comments.text:
Damn, it's ridiculous trying to leave comments going through Google!  Now 
for those that think this lady is one of the majority of "fake 
stories," damn, this is totally messed up!  Just because other countries 
have messed up gov'ts doesn't preclude North Korea from having the dire 
situation that currently exists and has existed there for many decades with 
THE most messed up government I've seen anywhere.  Have you not read Blaine 
Harden's book about Camp 14?  You have?  Good!  What's the complete title 
and who is the book about?  How long was he or she there?  Where was he/she 
born and where does he live now?  Is HIS or HER story true?  Ok, six 
questions...please answer each of them!  If you can't answer them, then 
you're wasting people's time with your stupid comments, that's all!﻿
